NOLA-PS anuncia el cierre de escuelas y la cancelación de todas las actividades escolares para el lunes y martes de esta semana debido a la tormenta tropical Marco. Estos cierres también afectarán a las comidas preparadas que se ofrecen a las familias para recogida.

El distrito continuará monitoreando las dos tormentas en los próximos días y reevaluará las necesidades de cierres adicionales debido a la tormenta tropical Laura mientras continuamos aprendiendo más sobre los posibles impactos en nuestra área.
.
.
NOLA-PS thông báo đóng cửa và hủy bỏ tất cả các sinh hoạt tại các cơ sở trường học ngày thứ Hai và thứ Ba của tuần này do cơn bão nhiệt đới Marco. Sự đóng cửa sẽ làm ảnh hưởng đến việc chuẩn bị các bữa ăn cho các gia đình đến nhận.

Ty học chánh sẽ tiếp tục theo dõi hai cơn bão này trong vài ngày tới và sẽ đánh giá lại nhu cầu đóng cửa lâu hơn do cơn bão nhiệt đới Laura trong lúc chúng tôi tiếp tục tìm hiểu thêm về sự tác đến khu vực của chúng ta.

post_text: Ernest N. "Dutch" Morial was a civil rights trailblazer whose career included many firsts for an African American in Louisiana. Graduating from Xavier University, a historically black Catholic institution in 1951, he became the first African American to receive a law degree from Louisiana State University in 1954. Battling segregation in the courtroom, he was elected president of the local NAACP chapter. In 1967 Morial became the first African American elected to the Louisiana State legislature since Reconstruction. Later, he became the first Juvenile Court judge in 1970, and the first African American Circuit Court of Appeals judge in Louisiana in 1974. In 1977 Morial was elected the first African American Mayor of New Orleans and served two terms in office, from 1978 to 1986.

post_text: Oretha Castle Haley is a civil rights pioneer who dedicated her life to social justice issues including education, healthcare, and poverty. As a student at Southern University in New Orleans, she became active in civil rights by participating in the Dryades Street Boycott in 1960. The boycott protested the fact that, although the area was frequented by black shoppers, no African-Americans were hired there. Haley went on to become a founding member of the Congress for Racial Equality. She later helped found, Voices of the New Orleans Movement, a group dedicated to commemorating the history of the civil rights movement in New Orleans. In 2006, the upper part of the street was renamed in her honor.

In 1985, the Orleans Parish School Board unanimously selected Dr. Everett Williams as the first African-American Superintendent of Schools. A New Orleans native, Dr. Everett served for over thirty-five years as an administrator at schools including McDonogh 35 High School and Carter G. Woodson Junior High School.

As Superintendent, Dr. Everett instituted programs such as Dollars for Schools, the Superintendent’s Academic Awards, and won taxpayer approvals for more classroom resources. Today, the Orleans Parish School Board meets in a boardroom named in his honor.
